div1.p: Flippen asks Kean for his opinion about some of the early influences on Walter Reed as a scientist and physician. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from James Carroll Flippen to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 4, 1938
div1.opener:
UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA
DEPARTMENT OF MEDICINE
CHARLOTTESVILLE
OFFICE OF THE DEAN
April 4, 1938.
Col. J. Randolph Kean,
2804 M Street, N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Col. Kean:
div1.p:
Your kind letter of March third was duly received, but found me
so much occupied with urgent matters that it is only until now that I have
had the opportunity of writing you further. The questions I have in mind
are doubtless difficult ones for anybody to answer, but I thought possibly
you might be in possession of certain information that might permit a re-
ply.

In reviewing Dr. Walter Reed's life the very striking thing to
me is the fact that at the age of forty or thereabouts he decided to go
into Bacteriology and Pathology. It seems likely to me that throughout
his medical career up to this time he had certain definite objectives,
which circumstances had until then denied him the opportunity of develop-
ing. In a brief statement in Dr. Kelly's History of Walter Reed, Welch
expressed the opinion that Reed had received his inspiration for scienti-
fic work during a period he spent in the Laboratory of Physiology at Johns
Hopkins in 1880. Of course, I would like to think that Dr. Reed received
at least a part of his inspiration at the University of Virginia, and in
going over his teachers here it seems more likely that he received inspir-
ation for a scientific career from Dr. James Lawrence Cabell than from any
of the other men with whom he had contacts.

It was unusual for a man in clinical work to have elected to
study Physiology in 1880 and I have wondered if anyone knows whether it
may be true that Dr. Reed resumed the study of Physiology through the for-
mer influence of Dr. Cabell. In going over the history of Dr. Reed's
life as it is recorded, I have not been able to find that any particular
person with whom he came in contact had a very definite influence over
his concepts and his life until his work with Welch about 1890 and the
brilliant group of young investigators with whom he was associated in
Welch's laboratory.

I also have not been able to find out what preparation he had
if any for the study of Bacteriology and Pathology when he went to Balti-
more in 1890. When he was at the University there was no medical or
biological subject in which microscopic work was done and, of course, this
was some years before any medical school had a course in Bacteriology.
In a recent conversation with Dr. Hume, Dr. Hume told me that he had rea-
son to think that Dr. Reed owned a microscope prior to the time he went
to Johns Hopkins, but this was rather unusual due to the fact that he had
no early training in microscopic work and he had then been stationed at
western army posts for a good many years.

Col. J. Randolph Kean - page two
4-3-38.

I hesitate to impose upon you in view of what you tell me of
your physical limitations, but if you could reply in brief to these
questions in my mind it would mean a good deal to me.

Understanding from what I have said above the real purport
of this letter, if you can add any other facts that would bear upon
this I would be greatly obliged to you.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J. C. Flippin. ----------
JCF:FS.
Dean Flippen.
